title: Man who survived beheading attack at Leytonstone Tube station says Trump's terror attack list 'helping ISIS'

A man who survived being stabbed at a London Tube station has slammed Donald Trump for including it among a list of 'terror attacks' ignored by the media. 
Lyle Zimmerman, 56, was attacked by Muhaddin Mire, 30, with a rusty knife at Leytonstone Underground station in December 2015. 
Mire 'sawed' at victims Lyle Zimmerman's neck - leaving him in a pool of blood - before lunging at other passengers. 
Although a court heard Mire had become obsessed with Islamic extremism, he was also diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia and suffered a persecution complex. 
He also believed he was possessed by spirits and Tony Blair was his 'guardian angel'. 
Mire was ultimately convicted of attempted murder and sentenced to life in prison 
He had already admitted four counts of attempted wounding in relation to other passengers. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Share this video Watch Next 
The White House listed the incident among 78 'terror attacks' since 2014 which "did not receive adequate attention from Western media sources." 
But Mr Zimmerman disagreed and said Trump's references to the dangers of Islamic extremism are only making the situation worse. 
He told The Independent: "For the White House, thatâ€™s not good enough. 
"I felt like it was heavily covered and also not actually an act of terrorism. 
"It was obvious to me that the event was ripe for sensationalisation, and that was going to help Isis and help far right extremists as well by making it this big, terrifying event. 
"I was very clear in my mind within a day or so of the attack that it was just a mental health tragedy. 
"This guy had had a really profound history of mental illness and his family had been trying to get him help." 
Mr Zimmerman, a musician, was attacked by Mire as they travelled on the same train from Stratford to Leytonstone, where the knifeman lived alonn. CCTV footage showed Mr Zimmerman being approached from behind (Photo: PA) Mire then left his victim in a pool of blood The rampage continued after Mire tapped out with an Oyster card and went up to street level 
Mire went on to lunge at other passengers with the rusty blade while shouting he was attacking people for "my Syrian brothers". 
Mr Zimmerman said he was "fortunate" to have received prompt first aid treatment at the scene from a passing junior doctor. 
In a statement read during Mire's sentencing hearing at the Old Bailey in London, he said he was "quite lucky" to have survived. 
"I have been left with a scar on my neck which I am aware of only because it pulls when I use my voice but is otherwise superficial and healing well," he said. 
Mr Zimmerman suffered from "flashing lights" in his vision for months after the attack. Mire was convicted at the Old Bailey last month (Photo: Metropolitan Police) Muhiddin Mire knifed Lyle Zimmerman after following him off a train 
"I am somewhat more cautious about interacting with strangers since the attack - overall I have not been significantly traumatised by the attack psychologically," he added. 
Prosecutor Jonathan Rees QC praised him for his "philosophical view" of his injuries. 
He also commended a number of passers-by who intervened in the attack. 
"There were a number of individuals who behaved with conspicuous bravery. Mr Zimmerman said he still suffers from his neck injuries 
Dr Shaun Bhattacherjee, a consultant psychiatrist treating Mire at Broadmoor Hospital, said he was "clearly mentally ill at the time of the events". 
"It is clear at the time of the offence he was very psychotic and manifested a significant number of psychotic symptoms," he said. 
He added that Mire poses a "very severe" risk to the public and needs ongoing psychiatric treatment. Brave passengers were praised for capturing footage of the rampage Many witnesses recorded the attacks on mobile phones 
"Because of the significant risk to the safety of others ... it's necessary that that treatment is continued in conditions of high security." 
Alphege Bell, defending, said Mire suffered from a number of unfounded beliefs, including that " Tony Blair was his guardian angel". 
He also thought he was possessed by evil spirits and underwent a number of "exorcisms" by imams. 
Mire has been diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia and suffered his first episode of psychosis in 2006, the court heard. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
